meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: Linsey nice to see you on the screen. We've exchanged emails before but nice to virtually meet you.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Linsey Seitz
meeting_annotations.transcript: Nice to virtually meet you as well. Looking forward to hosting you.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: I'm looking forward. I'm going to do my best to be there in person finally.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Linsey Seitz
meeting_annotations.transcript: That would be lovely. But definitely no pressure, okay, if it just doesn't happen. These are wild times.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: It should be I think it should be okay by then. As God willing.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Linsey Seitz
meeting_annotations.transcript: Fingers crossed.
meeting_annotations.other: Linsey makes a 'fingers crossed' gesture with her hand.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: It's a little bizarre we have two bots. Anyway, Jordy's going to be joining us late so I you're stuck with me as the as the single facilitator for the first bit. And I see familiar faces in at least three of you have been in sessions with me before but I think we should do a round of introductions. So I'll just start really quickly and just say I'm Emily Carter, I'm the Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost at UCLA and I work on a variety of of sustainable energy technologies including carbon dioxide reduction which is what we're here to discuss today. So it's not actually I shouldn't say that it shouldn't be limited right to just carbon dioxide. It's also methane and other possible greenhouse gases. So with that, can I ask Caroline for you to introduce yourself and just say which department you're in at Utah and your and your interests?
meeting_annotations.other: Emily points out the presence of two bots in the participant list.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Caroline Saouma
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah so I'm Caroline Saouma. I'm an assistant professor at the University of Utah in the Department of Chemistry. And my interests are really thinking about I guess most of us are here, you know CO2 conversion to higher products and really thinking about bridging the the classical or the you know more traditional hydrogenation literature and knowledge with that for electrocatalysis. And then moreover thinking how do we interface you know like captured CO2 with CO2 catalysis since we always just use you know a clean stream of CO2 gas when we do catalysis. Is that the best approach to study these problems?
meeting_annotations.other: Uses hand gestures to emphasize points about bridging different fields.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great, thank you. Kelsey?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Kelsey Hatzell
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi. I think I've met most people here at this point but I'm Kelsey Hatzell, assistant professor at Princeton in Mechanical Engineering and the Andlinger Center. My group works on electrochemical systems both from the conversion side and the storage side and so we are interested in some small molecule activation and really looking at how we can use electrochemical systems to get dynamic interfaces and how we can design interrogation and diagnostic tools to look at interfaces in operando conditions.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great. Linsey?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Linsey Seitz
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, I'm Linsey Seitz. I'm an assistant professor at Northwestern, the Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering. My group's experimental, so we work on a variety of electrocatalytic processes, so CO2 reduction, a lot of fun selective oxidations to make chemicals and fuels, mostly on mixed metal oxide catalysts as a really highly tunable platform. Also looking at tuning and understanding the structure of that electrochemical double layer, how that influences our catalysis. And finally, heavy emphasis on in situ and operando spectroscopy, so mostly synchrotron-based but a little bit of vibrational to be looking at dynamic catalyst response to reaction conditions.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great. Jose?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jose Mendoza
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi everyone. I'm Jose Mendoza. I do atomistic and quantum simulations especially for low dimensional materials and my interest is on carbon capture in different different ways and lately has I have been doing a lot of catalysis multiscale simulations especially oriented for machine learning and property structure-property relationships.
meeting_annotations.other: Uses a virtual background with mathematical equations.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great. Wilson?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Wilson Smith
meeting_annotations.transcript: Everyone, Wilson Smith. I have a joint appointment at CU Boulder in the Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering and at NREL as a senior scientist. At NREL we focus on scaling up electrochemical technologies to the megawatt-ish scale in terms of reactor design and implementation. And between CU and NREL we do a lot of operando spectroelectrochemistry and microscopy for reaction mechanisms.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: Jimmy?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jimmy Jiang
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi everyone. I'm Jimmy Jiang from University of Cincinnati. My research interest is about how to design molecular catalysts for small molecule activation and conversion including carbon dioxide.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: Shu?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Shu Hu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi everyone. This is Shu, Shu Hu from Yale University, Chemical Engineering. I'm also joined with the Energy Science Institute on the West Campus. My group works on the heterogeneous photocatalysts. So these are the reactions that under solar photochemistry and we initially work on the solar hydrogen production but now we are extending the reaction systems to methane oxidation and other carbon-carbon coupling processes and also recently working on the photoredox organic synthesis but on photocatalyst surfaces. So what we're aspired to is actually the the practical side of photocatalysis, heterogeneous catalysis where you can ease the reactor design but also drive chemistry at room temperature by using light and other means. So the relevance to this is actually we also work on electrocatalysis but actually in the context of comparing the electron transfer processes for photo versus electro. So really nice to meet all of you. I think especially for Professor Carter, this is the first time we met. So really honored to be here.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: It's very nice to meet you. Eva?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Eva Nichols
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi everyone. I'm Eva Nichols. I'm an assistant professor at the University of British Columbia in Canada. My lab works on electrochemical CO2 reduction catalysis, both molecular catalysts, largely metalloporphyrin systems, as well as molecularly modified metal surfaces. I also have an interest in vibrational spectroscopies at the interface and in solution. So working on ATR-SEIRAS approaches as well as time-resolved IR in solution. Nice to meet you.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great. So our next job is to pick a scribe and a reporter and I know Wilson is off limits since he did it with me last time and I think Kelsey's already done it. And so I don't remember if you've done it or not but I'd really like you to step up if possible.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Linsey Seitz
meeting_annotations.transcript: Sorry, I also already went yesterday.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Eva Nichols
meeting_annotations.transcript: Me too. As did I.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: Oh that's right. Okay so Jose, Jimmy and Shu, have you done it before? Okay so by process of elimination.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jimmy Jiang
meeting_annotations.transcript: I can do the recording.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: Sorry, who's who said that? Jimmy? The recorder? Yeah. Okay, so you'll take notes.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jimmy Jiang
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I'll take notes.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, so you should be able to make sure that you can access the Google Drive. It's I think section 3.2 you need to be taking notes on. Do you want me to share a screen to show you where it is?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jimmy Jiang
meeting_annotations.transcript: Is it slide 43?

meeting_annotations.transcript: I sent a link to the rough notes, or if you want you can do it directly in the slides, but you can start with longer format in the rough notes section.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Emily Carter
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, let's definitely start I think with the rough notes.

meeting_annotations.transcript: No no no, the Google Doc is there. I'm going to show you. I'm going to I have way too many things open but let me see if I can show you what it looks like. Okay.
